item.description:
All right... so we had a big old house drop in on us this past weekend, squashing our plans like they were some sort of female malevolent sorcerer who’s maleficium behavior is believed to come from some deep inner intangible diabolus.


But that’s ok!!!... we got heart, and we got brains, and yes… that’s right… we got chocolate. Courage too, but who needs courage when we got hearts & brains & chocolate (kinda sounds like a recipe for French haute cuisine).


As I was saying... we had a big old house squash our plans, and now that the “house lifting, witch crushing” storm has passed, it’s time to get our plans out from underneath the floorboards, slip on those magical hiking boots of ours, and let them carry us to the very adventures we had intended.


Said to be one of the most popular day hikes in the White Mountains, the Franconia Ridge loop over Haystack, Lincoln and Lafayette is also said to be, at the very very least, strenuous. Approx. 9 miles long, nearly 4000 feet of elevation gain, no less than 5 stream crossings, the possibility of some major weather/temp changes, and somewhere's in the neighborhood of 8+ hrs on the trail. The reward??? Scenic cascade after scenic cascade, two 5000 foot summits, one 4700 foot summit, a “knife edge” col, panoramic views galore, regular views galore, a mountain pond and… wait for it… wait for it… a shiny rock!!!

With all this in mind, along with the shorter days and colder air, we’ll begin at 8:30am, giving us just about 9 1/2 - 10 hours of daylight to complete the loop; we’ll hike the loop in a counter-clock wise direction.



Starting at the Old Bridle Path trailhead, we’ll hike for 0.2 miles and then bear right onto and ascend Falling Waters Trail, summit Little Haystack, and then turn left to follow the Franconia Ridge Trail north to Lincoln and Lafayette. After we spin around 3 times and spit into the wind (optional), or take advantage of a "planking" photo-op (also optional), we’ll then head west and descend from Lafayette via the Greenleaf Trail to the AMC Hut (potable water and bathrooms available). From here, we’ll leave the hut and the Greenleaf Trail behind and descend SSW on the Old Bridle Path Trail to our awaiting cars.



Note: Franconia Ridge is extremely susceptible to high winds and bad weather, and is particularly exposed and prone to severe lightning strikes. Hikers are advised to pay particular attention to weather conditions for the area and avoid the ridge crest on Mts. Lafayette, Lincoln and Little Haystack when storms approach. So, poor weather will cancel this hike or, quite possibly, force us to turn around.

Cool Weather/Fall Essentials (required):
• Synthetic Quick-drying Pants
• Synthetic Quick-drying L/S Shirt
• Sturdy Hiking Boots/shoes
• Synthetic/Wool Socks
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket
• Light/Mid-weight Insulating Layers (undershirt/underpants)
• Extra pair of Socks
• Hat/Gloves
• Rain/Soft Shell Jacket/Pants
• Water (2-3L)
• Headlamp/Flashlight
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)

the Remaining Essentials:
• Medications/First Aid Supplies
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's hardly a reason not to have one in your pack)
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellant/Toiletries
• Light-weight Wind Jacket (if your insulated or rain jacket isn’t windproof)
• Hand Warmers
• Trekking Poles
• Gaiters
• Light-weight Emergency Shelter
• Camera/Binoculars

Important:
NO JEANS, NO SNEAKERS, NO COTTON CLOTHING... that includes underwear too!!! (They get wet, They stay wet & They won’t keep you warm.) 

ALSO, LET'S NOT UNDERESTIMATE ANYTHING, these are the White Mountains in early October, so come prepared for the worst: cold cold temps., wet weather, early darkness and lots of wind.

 

Directions:
Follow I-93 north past exit 34A. Continue past “The Basin” exit  for about a mile and a half and take the exit marked “TRAILHEAD PARKING.” Look for a grey Jetta w/ CT plates -- Note: There is parking on the southbound side of I-93 @ The Lincoln Place Campground exit, should the northbound lot be full.

From Providence: 3 hours 15 minutes
From Newport: 3 hours 45 minutes

Google Maps:
http://maps.google.com/maps?q=Trailhead+Parking,+Lincoln...


Additional Information:
Mount Layafette: 5260 feet*
Mount Lincoln: 5089 feet*
Little Haystack Mt: 4780 feet
* numbers 6 & 7 on the NH 4,000 Footers Lists

 

Distance (loop): 8.9 miles*
Elevation Gain (total): 3,850 ft
Exposure: Full (approx. 2+ miles/ 2+ hrs)
Difficulty: Strenuous/Level 4
Pace: Moderate
Book Time (not including stops): 6:25 hrs
Approx. Hike Time (including stops): 8:00+ hrs
* does not include Shining Rock detour

 

Time Goals:
Little Haystack: 12:00pm
Lafayette: 2:00pm
AMC Greenleaf Hut: 3:00pm*
* this should give us about 3 hrs of daylight to get off the mountain

Sunrise: 6:53 a.m.
Sunset: 6:15 p.m.
Twilight ends: 6:44 p.m.
(according to the US Naval Observatory)

Approx. Temp. Hi: mid to high 60’s
Approx. Temp. Lo: mid to hign 40’s*
* as of Sept 17th, summit temps. have already been recorded in the 30’s
